Research article Temperature-dependent switchable synthesis of imines and amines via coupling of alcohols and amines using pyrrolyl-imine ruthenium catalysts Ran Liu Investigation Data curation Yujia Hou Methodology Investigation Mengxuan Bai Data curation Formal analysis Zhangang Han Formal analysis Zhiqiang Hao Writing – original draft Supervision ⁎ Jin Lin Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Hebei Technology Innovation Center for Energy Conversion Materials and Devices, Hebei Key Laboratory of Organic Functional Molecules, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang 050024, China Hebei Technology Innovation Center for Energy Conversion Materials and Devices, Hebei Key Laboratory of Organic Functional Molecules College of Chemistry and Materials Science Hebei Normal University Shijiazhuang 050024 China Hebei Technology Innovation Center for Energy Conversion Materials and Devices, Hebei Key Laboratory of Organic Functional Molecules, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang 050024, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of pyrrolyl-imine supported Ru(II) complexes 2a-2d were prepared and used as efficient catalysts for chemodivergent coupling of alcohols and amines to give imines 5 and amines 6 in 48–99 % yields. Notably, the selectivity in this reaction is simply governed by the reaction temperature. The current catalytic system was carried out in an open atmosphere in air with low catalyst loading (0.1 mol%) and displayed good functional-group compatibility. Keywords Dehydrogenation Borrowing hydrogen Temperature control C-N bond formation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The construction of carbon–nitrogen bond is of considerable importance in the field of organic chemistry [1]. Nitrogenous compounds such as amines and imines are key structural motifs due to their prevalence in many pharmaceuticals, natural products, fine chemical and functional materials [2,3]. The methods for the synthesis of amines via Buchwald-Hartwig amination [4], Ullmann coupling [5], hydroamination [6] and the formation of imines by acid-catalyzed condensation of aldehydes (or ketones) with amines or oxidative coupling of amines [7] were well investigated. However, most of these reactions suffer from the use of alkyl halide or resulting in copious waste. Thus, there is an increasing demand for developing new protocols for the formation of C-N bonds in an atom-economical and sustainable manner. In this respect, using cheap and easy-to-handle alcohols [8] as alkylating reagents has attracted significant attention. A variety of nitrogen sources like nitro [9], nitrile [10], hydrazine [11], arylamine [12] and others [13] were employed as coupling partners to efficiently construct C-N bonds (Scheme 1 a). In addition, the acceptorless dehydrogenative coupling (ADC) [14,15] for the preparation of imines and borrowing hydrogen (BH) [16,17] strategy for the synthesis of amines have gained great attention in the recent years. Both reactions are attractive, which proceed in one pot without using any oxidants and generate water and (or) hydrogen, respectively as the only by-products (Scheme 1b). Among various homogeneous transition-metal catalysts, noble metals of ruthenium [18] and iridium [19] were firstly explored in such transformations and has progressed significantly over the last decade. From a synthetic perspective, it would be more efficient and practical to switch synthesis of amines and imines from the same alcohol and amine couples. However, only a handful of examples have been reported to control selectivity over imine or amine synthesis via the ADC or BH routes (Scheme 1c). The pioneering works revealed that the adjustment of reaction factors such as the use of different bases or catalysts [20], addition of molecular sieves [21] and altering reaction atmosphere [22] significantly affect the yield ratio of amine and imine. More recently, Liu and co-workers reported a temperature-controlled amines/imines synthesis catalyzed by the Mo(CO)6/organocatalyst binary system [23]. Guided by the above excellent works and motivated by our continuous interests in C-N bond formation [24], herein, we report the synthesis, characterization, and reactivity of a series of ruthenium complexes possessing simple pyrrolyl-imine ligands [25]. These Ru complexes were found to be highly efficient catalysts for coupling of arylamines with alcohols to chemodivergent synthesis of imines and amines at different reaction temperature (Scheme 1c). 2 Result and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characteriztion of Ru complexes The bidentate pyrrole-imine ligands 1a-1d were prepared in high yields by the condensation of pyrrole-2-aldehyde with para-substituted anilines in hexane [26]. The corresponding Ru complexes 2a-2d were synthesized in 81–88 % yields following the literature procedure via reaction of ligands 1a-1d with RuHCl(CO)(PPh3)3 in the presence of KOH at room temperature (Scheme 2 ) [27]. These Ru(II) complexes were well characterized by NMR, IR and HR-MS. It is noteworthy that complexes 2a-2c were also synthesized in two steps reported by Bhattacharya starting from pyrrole-imine ligands and Ru(CO)2(PPh3)3 [28a]. In the 1H NMR spectra of ruthenium complexes 2a-2d, the singlets observed around 7.1 ppm were assigned to the C = N protons. The characteristic hydride signals were found at −10.8 ppm as triplets due to coupling with two equivalent PPh3 groups. The infrared visible spectra of the complexes 2a-2d showed absorption bands in the range of 1557–1567 cm−1, which are the characteristic absorption peaks of the imine bonds. The strong stretching bands observed within 1902–1922 cm−1 are due to the coordinated CO group. The HR-MS analysis also matched well with their molecular structures. The single-crystal structures of complexes 2b-2d were further confirmed by X-ray crystallographic determinations (Figs. 1-3 ). The crystallographic data are summarized in Table S1 (see the Supporting Information). In the solid state, the Ru metal center is surrounded by the bidentate NN ligand, two PPh3 ligands, a chloride anion and a hydride in a distorted-octahedral geometry. The Ru-H bonds in complexes 2b-2d are in the range of 1.55–1.63 Å, which are similar to the values in 2a reported by Bhattacharya [28a] and pyridyl-based Ru-H complex [28b]. The Ru-Npyrrolyl bond lengths range from 2.154 to 2.171 Å, which are longer than those (2.073 and 2.138 Å) in the similar pyrrolyl-imine Ru and pyridyl-based NN-Ru complexes [29]. The P-Ru-P angles in 2b-2d are 175.13–177.29°, suggesting that the two PPh3 ligands are almost linearly positioned. 2.2 Catalytic synthesis of imines and amines At the beginning of the study, benzyl alcohol 3a and aniline 4a were selected as the model starting material to examine the reaction. We have carefully screened various Ru catalysts, base, solvent and reaction temperature (Table 1 ). After screening different reaction parameters, the optimal reaction conditions were found as follows: catalyst 2a (0.1 mol %), KOH (0.5 equiv) in 2.0 mL of toluene at 90 °C for 18 h. Under this condition, imine 5a could be obtained in 97 % GC yield (Table 1, entry 1). Using other bases such as NaOH, t BuONa, K2CO3 and DBU gave a low yield or trace amount of the product 5a (entries 2–5). From various solvents screened, toluene was found to be the most suitable solvent for this ADC reaction (entries 6–8). Lowering the loading of KOH or catalyst 2a displayed slightly lower efficiency (entries 9–10). Reducing or increasing the reaction temperature has a negative impact on imine yield (entries 11–12). In order to verify whether the air (O2) promotes this catalytic reaction, we then carried out the same reaction in nitrogen atmosphere and 93 % yield of 5a was obtained (entry 13). This result may be inferred that air did not participate in this coupling reaction. Control experiments revealed that catalyst 2a and KOH were indispensable in the reaction (entries 14–15). Other Ru catalysts 2b-2d were also explored under the optimizing conditions and their catalytic activities are somewhat lower than that of 2a (entries 16–18). Under the optimal conditions, we then explored the scope and limitation of the reaction (Table 2 ). A wide range of benzyl alcohols can be used in the present reaction to selectively give the imine products in moderate to excellent yields. The substrates having both electron-donating (e.g. Me, OMe, i Pr) and electron-withdrawing (e.g. F, Cl, Br) groups on the aryl ring of benzyl alcohols were reacted well with 4a to afforded the desired imines 5b-5 k in excellent yields (94–98 %). It is noteworthy that the steric hindrance from the aryl moiety of the benzyl alcohol substrates had no impact on the reaction efficiency. For example, the OMe group at different position of benzyl alcohols gave the corresponding products 5d-5f in > 94 % yields. In particular, the heteroaromatic alcohols like furan-2-ylmethanol and thiophen-2-ylmethanol were efficiently converted to the corresponding imine products 5 l and 5 m in 84 % and 93 % yields, respectively. However, pyridin-2-ylmethanol was less efficient to give the product 5n in 48 %. This may be attributed to the strong coordination ability of the pyridine nitrogen atom to the metal center, leading to the deactivation of the catalyst. In addition, the naphthalen-2-ylmethanol was also worked well, resulting almost quantitative conversion to product 5o. Unfortunately, the aliphatic alcohols were not compatible with this method in imine synthesis. During the optimizing the reaction conditions for the synthesis of imine products, it was found that reaction temperature has an influence on imine/amine selectivity to some extent (Table 1, entries 11–12). Similar results could also be observed in Mo- and Mn-catalyzed ADC or BH reactions [30]. Based on the above experiments and previous reports, we further explored the influence of reaction temperature on this coupling reaction. As shown in Fig. 4 , when the reaction was performed at 90 °C, imine 5a was obtained as major product in 97 % yield with only trace amount of amine 6a was found. Delightfully, the yield of amine 6a gradually increased with the increase of reaction temperature (90 to 130 °C) and reached the maximum yield of 96 % at 130 °C, reflecting excellent temperature-controlled distribution of products. With the optimal reaction conditions in hand (See Supporting information, Table S2) [31], the substrate scope of amine synthesis was investigated (Table 3 ). As shown, various anilines underwent catalytic reactions smoothly with different benzyl alcohols and aliphatic alcohols to selectivity deliver the amine products in good to excellent yields. At first, aniline 4a reacted with different benzyl alcohols bearing electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents in the phenyl ring led to satisfied results. In most cases, excellent yields of the desired amine 6a-6k were obtained, except for the fluoro-substituted benzyl alcohol displayed moderate efficiency to give the product 6h in 66 % yield. In addition, the O- and S-containing benzyl alcohols were well tolerated, giving the desired amines 6l and 6m in > 95 % yields. Similar to imine synthesis, a significant decrease in yield of amine 6n was observed when pyridine-based benzyl alcohol was applied. The bulky naphthalen-2-ylmethanol almost completely converted to the amine product 6o under the optimized conditions. Furthermore, alkyl alcohols are found to be suitable for this reaction. Linear primary alcohols coupled well with aniline 4a to afford the corresponding products 6p-6r in 86–93 % yields. The anilines bearing representative electron-donating methyl groups and electron-withdrawing Cl and Br groups were all well tolerated to generate the corresponding amine products 6s-6w in 65–88 % yields. It is worth mentioning that the halo-substituted imines or amines were obtained in good yields, which could serve as an excellent functional group handle for various late-stage functionalization. Notably, the present catalytic system could be also employed to synthesize diamine. For instance, reaction of 1,3-diaminobenzene with benzyl alcohol 3a smoothly led to the target product 6x in 80 % yield. As shown in Scheme 3 , the application potential of the present catalytic system is also presented. The reaction could be performed at gram scale to give the product 6a in 85 % yield. Furthermore, Ru-catalyzed coupling of the resulting 6a with excess of glycol in refluxing toluene for 3 days afforded the key intermediate 7 in 63 % yield, which could be further converted into pharmaceutical Antergan 8 (Antihistamine) in 65 % yield according to a previous report [32]. In order to gain some insights into the reaction mechanism, a few control experiments were carried out, as depicted in Scheme 4 . The yield of 6a was not affected when the reaction was carried out under standard conditions (amine synthesis) in the presence of excess Hg, suggesting the homogeneous nature of the reaction (Scheme 4a) [33]. This result also demonstrated that the bidentate pyrrolyl-imine ligand can effectively stabilize the metal center during the catalytic reaction to prevent catalyst deactivation and also exploit the opportunity of tuning catalytic efficiency through substituent modification of the ligands. The reaction of benzyl alcohol 3a with imine 5a under standard reaction conditions furnished amine 6a in 91 %, indicating that hydrogen source originated from benzyl alcohol and the formation of Ru-H species during the reaction (Scheme 4b) [34]. When the reaction was run in the presence of KOH, the condensation of benzaldehyde 3a’ with aniline 4a resulted in the formation of imine 5a with or without catalyst 2a in 88 % and 85 % yields, respectively and no hydrogenation product 6a was observed (Scheme 4c). These results indicated that benzaldehyde 3a’ is the intermediate in the ADC reaction for imine synthesis. Furthermore, the detection of hydrogen gas formation in the process of imine synthesis was confirmed by GC analysis (See Supporting information). Based on the above experiments and literatures [35], a reasonable formation amines mechanism of imines and amines is illustrated in Scheme 5 . The reaction of precatalyst Ru(II) complex 2a with benzyl alcohol 3a gives the Ru-alkoxide complex I accompanied by the extrusion of one molecule of H2 and PPh3. The β-H elimination then occurs to afford the ruthenium hydride species II and promotes the dehydrogenation of alcohol to aldehyde. The base-mediated condensation reaction of aldehyde with amine produces the imine compound 5a. On the one hand, the ruthenium hydride species II reacts with another molecule of benzyl alcohol 3a at a relatively low reaction temperature (90 °C) to regenerate Ru-alkoxide complex I, releases H2 gas and finish the ADC catalytic cycle (path a). On the other hand, the Ru-H species II is more prone to react with imine 5a at a high reaction temperature (130 °C) to form Ru-amino intermediate III. Finally, the reaction of intermediate III with benzyl alcohol 3a provides the N-alkylated amine product to complete the BH catalytic cycle and regenerate the Ru-alkoxide complex I (path b). Besides, the oxidative dehydrogenation process cannot be completely ruled out under present air condition [22a,36]. 3 Conclusions In summary, we describe an efficient and convenient method for highly selective synthesis of imines and amines by using well-defined NN-Ru complexes. The key to selectivity lies in the control of the reaction temperature. A diverse range of primary alcohols and amines were selectively transformed into imines or amines with good to excellent yields via ADC or BH routes. We anticipate that this sustainable and temperature-controlled approach will find more applications in organic synthesis, especially on selective alcohol transformation. 4 Experimental 4.1 General information The synthesis of Ru complexes 2a-2d was carried out under an inert nitrogen atmosphere using a standard Schlenk line. Unless otherwise noted, all starting materials were commercially available and were used without further purification. All of the solvents were distilled from the appropriate drying agents under N2 before use. IR spectra were recorded as potassium bromide pellets using a Thermo Fisher iS50 spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm−1. NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl3 by using a Zhongke-Niujin 400 MHz NMR spectrometer at room temperature. HRMS were acquired using an Agilent 6545 LC/Q-TOF mass spectrometer. GC measurements were performed on Agilent GC8890 equipment using an Agilent HP-5 column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm): injector temp. 320 °C, detector temp. 320 °C, column temp. 40 °C, withdraw time 2 min, then 20 °C to 260 °C over 15 min. 4.2 Synthesis of ruthenium complexes 2a-2d To a 25 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stir bar was added ligands 1a-1d (0.2 mmol), RuHCl(CO)(PPh3)3 (0.2 mmol), KOH (0.4 mmol) and CH3OH (5 mL). The reaction was stirred at room temperature for 12 h under a N2 atmosphere. After the reaction was completed, the crude products were collected by filtration and washed with cooled CH3OH (2 × 2 mL). HR-MS (ESI-TOF): calcd for C48H39BrN2OP2Ru, [M + H]+ 903.0837, found 903.0755. 4.3 General procedure for synthesis of imines Aniline 4 (1.0 mmol), alcohol 3 (1.5 mmol), catalyst 2a (0.1 mol%), KOH (0.5 mmol) and toluene (2.0 mL) were added in a 25 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stir bar under air condition. The flask was equipped with a condenser and the reaction was heated in an oil bath at 90 °C for 18 h. After cooling to room temperature, a small portion of the mixture was taken for GC analysis and the remaining solution was concentrated under vacuum to remove the solvent. The residue was then purified by column chromatography using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent to afford the corresponding imine product 5. 4.4 General procedure for synthesis of amines Aniline 4 (1.0 mmol), alcohol 3 (1.5 mmol), catalyst 2a (0.1 mol%), KOH (0.5 mmol) and toluene (2.0 mL) were added in a 25 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stir bar under air condition. The flask was equipped with a condenser and the reaction was heated in an oil bath at 130 °C for 18 h. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction was concentrated in vacuo and the residue was purified by neutral alumina column chromatography using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent to afford the corresponding amine product 6. coredata.dc:description: A series of pyrrolyl-imine supported Ru(II) complexes 2a-2d were prepared and used as efficient catalysts for chemodivergent coupling of alcohols and amines to give imines 5 and amines 6 in 48–99 % yields. Notably, the selectivity in this reaction is simply governed by the reaction temperature. The current catalytic system was carried out in an open atmosphere in air with low catalyst loading (0.1 mol%) and displayed good functional-group compatibility.

coredata.dc:title: Temperature-dependent switchable synthesis of imines and amines via coupling of alcohols and amines using pyrrolyl-imine ruthenium catalysts
